english: have nothing better to do (lit. stuffed from eating)

etymology.description: 吃饱了(ate one’s fill) + 撑的(so stuffed that ... ) = mocking someone as idle and doing pointless things.
etymology.interpretation: Used snidely to say someone is messing around because they’re too idle, as if overstuffed after a meal. Common in scolding like 你这是吃饱了撑的吧.
etymology.simplification: 飽→饱 compresses 食 to 饣 and keeps phonetic 包; 撐→撑 uses 扌 + 争 (simplified 爭), both reducing strokes for high-frequency colloquial forms.

parts.english: ate to fullness; full; finished eating; satiated
so stuffed; overfull; to the point of bursting; (colloq.) idle and looking for trouble

examples.chinese: 你这是吃饱了撑的吧(你這是吃飽了撐的吧)。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ zhè shì chī bǎo le chēng de ba.
examples.english: Are you just doing this because you have nothing better to do?

examples.chinese: 他闲得没事(他閒得沒事)，真是吃饱了撑的(真是吃飽了撐的)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xián de méi shì, zhēn shì chī bǎo le chēng de.
examples.english: He’s so idle—clearly has nothing better to do.

examples.chinese: 别在这儿瞎折腾(別在這兒瞎折騰)，吃饱了撑的才这样(吃飽了撐的才這樣)。
examples.pinyin: Bié zài zhèr xiā zhēteng, chī bǎo le chēng de cái zhèyàng.
examples.english: Don’t fool around here; only someone with nothing better to do acts like this.
